>
> I had a similar problem specifically with JUnitReport, which
> cannot be started in a forked JVM. The solution to that
> problem is to start ant itself with more java heap using the
> ANT_OPTS environment variable.
>
> The important point here is that ANT_OPTS is an operating
> system environment variable,...
> Try this where ever you define your JAVA_HOME and ANT_HOME, such as
> ~/.bash_profile:
>
> ANT_OPTS=-Xmx80M # do some tests to figure out the minimume
> size you need... JAVA_HOME=/javahome # or where ever...
> ANT_HOME=/anthome # or where ever... export $ANT_OPTS
> $JAVA_HOME $ANT_HOME
>

The real culprit was the line:
log4j.logger.net.sf.hibernate.tool.hbm2ddl=debug in the log4j properties
file. He was the guy who wad making the monster files.

thanks
